A new genus of Kimulidae; first record of the family from Colombia (Opliones, Grassatores)
Article
Full-text available
  • Aug 2019
  • Adriano Kury
  • Andrs F. Garca
  • Miguel Medrano
Usatama gen. nov. is described to include a new species of Kimulidae from Colombia. This is the first record of the family from the country. The new genus presents a weakly armed ocularium, feeble sexual dimorphism, and unique genital structure with three parallel horseshoe-shaped girdles in pars distalis and absence of cochleariform macrosetae.

Obscure priority: on the authorship of the nomen Sironidae (Arachnida, Opiliones)
Article
  • Jul 2019
  • Adriano Kury
The family nomen Sironidae, widely attributed to Simon (1879), but recently stated to have been made available 40 years before by C. L. Koch (1839), is now shown to be even older, dating of Leach (1816), in a publication never acknowledged in the arachnological literature.

Projects

Projects (13)
Taxonomic revision and cladistic analysis of Pachylospeleinae ilhav and Metagyndes Srensen and their respective genera putatively close phylogenetically (Arachnida: Opiliones: Gonyleptidae): tackling the Pachylinae poliphyly in two fronts
Project
The main goal of this project is three fold: 1. Revise the Chilean genera Metagyndes Srensen, Calcarogyndes Mello-Leito, Pseudogyndes and Gyndulus roeweri (Soares & Soares) and the putative clade composed of Pachylospeleus ilhav, Hypophyllonomus Giltay,, Pseudogyndesoides B. Soares, Gyndesoides Mello-Leito, Passosa Roewer, Singram Mello-Leito, Triglochinura Mello-Leito, Ogloblinia Canals and Uropachylus Mello-Leito. 2. Use the cladistic approach to test and propose monophyletic groups and their relationships. 3. Describe new species.
View
Systematics of superfamily Epedanoidea
Project
My primary work is in Gonyleptoidea, but I also develop many smaller projects of Podoctidae, Epedanidae and other members of this SE Asian assemblage of harvestmen.
View
  • 1 Update
Inventory of the Opiliones types of the Natural History Museum, London
Project
The project aims to critically list all type-specimens of the arachnid order Opiliones (harvestmen) in the NHM, London, by estimating what specimens should be deposited there, what is really present in the collection, their type-status, their systematic placement, former and current. There will be also a photographic records of the specimens and their labels. This project is being developed in partnership with the NHM curator, Janet Beccaloni and Daniella Sherwood.
